September 22, 1985: Fiction
LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $17.95.) Recollections of a
small town.
LUCKY, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The heiress of a crime
lord takes on the heiress of a shipping tycoon.
THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Naval Institute Press,
$14.95.) A Lithuanian submarine driver defects to the United States.
SKELETON CREW, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $18.95.) Twenty-two tales of
contemporary horror.
THE TWO MRS. GRENVILLES, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $14.95.) Romance,
scandal and murder in New York's high society.
THE FOURTH DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $17.95.) Which of
six suspects murdered a saintly New York psychiatrist?
LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The Old
West larger than life.
THE CIDER HOUSE RULES, by John Irving. (Morrow, $18.95.) Life in a Maine
orphanage earlier in this century.
A MAGGOT, by John Fowles. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Five travelers in 18th-
century England have mysterious, wonderful and eerie adventures.
THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $16.95.) His family and
female friends impose order of a kind on the errant life of a travel writer.
IF TOMORROW COMES, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $17.95.) A young woman
destroys the crime lords who got her an undeserved prison term.
LESS THAN ZERO, by Bret Easton Ellis. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.) The
hedonistic lives of Los Angeles's rich kids.
TOO MUCH, TOO SOON, by Jacqueline Briskin. (Putnam, $17.95.) Three sisters
find their destinies bound by an obsession with the same man.
AFTER THE REUNION, by Rona Jaffe. (Delacorte, $17.95.) The surprises and
betrayals four Radcliffe women encountered in the five years after their 25th
reunion.
JUBAL SACKETT, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $16.95.) A restless explorer scouts
the 17th-century American wilderness.
HOLD THE DREAM, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Continuing
September 22, 1985
Non-Fiction
YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.)
From West Virginia hillbilly to World War II fighter pilot to the first man to fly faster
than sound.
IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam,
$19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler.
ELVIS AND ME, by Priscilla Beaulieu Presley with Sandra Harmon. (Putnam,
$16.95.) The rock legend as friend, mentor, lover, husband and father of a
daughter, by his former wife.
A PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE, by Tom Peters and Nancy Austin. (Random
House, $19.95.) Ways to achieve distinction in management.
SMART WOMEN, FOOLISH CHOICES, by Connell Cowan and Melvyn Kinder.
(Clarkson N. Potter, $13.95.) Two clinical psychologists analyze the successes
and failures of modern women in looking for acceptable men.
LOVING EACH OTHER, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack/Holt, $13.95.) Suggestions for
''setting our priorities right in order to enjoy life to the fullest.''
CONFESSIONS OF A HOOKER, by Bob Hope with Dwayne Netland. (Doubleday,
$17.95.) Memories of more than 50 years of golfing, by the comedian.
HAMMER OF THE GODS: The Led Zeppelin Saga, by Stephen Davis. (Morrow,
$15.95.) The British heavy metal group's boisterous tours of the 1970's.
THE AMATEURS, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $14.95.) Four American men
seek the 1984 Olympic gold medal for single sculling.
THE MICK, by Mickey Mantle with Herb Gluck. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The
autobiography of the Oklahoma farm boy who became a New York Yankee
baseball star.
FINAL CUT, by Steven Bach. (Morrow, $19.95.) How the making of the film
''Heaven's Gate'' proved the unmaking of United Artists.
FUNNY MONEY, by Mark Singer. (Knopf, $15.95.) The scandal surrounding the
1982 collapse of the Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City.
MARTINA, by Martina Navratilova with George Vecsey. (Knopf, $16.95.) The
autobiography of the Czechoslovak-born tennis champion.
RE-INVENTING THE CORPORATION, by John Naisbitt and Patricia Aburdene.
(Warner, $17.50.) A description of ''the new information society'' and its
opportunities for employees and employers.
